The EHL minimum film thickness occurrence highlights the completion of the corresponding events. The initiation and completion positions are paired using both angular positions and directions. The angular intervals are smaller at the parts of engine cycle where greater film variations are available. The direction of the events depends on the predicted directions in the EHL minimum film thickness occurrence and the minimum film squeeze velocity criteria.

Crankshaft main bearings and connecting rod bearings have motion clearance space. Under the external excitation of combustion and inertial forces, they are likely to generate vibration and noise at some operating conditions. The radial motion of the

journal and the vibration of the crankshaft system are likely to result in impact due to the existence of a large clearance. In the process of load transmission from combustion pressure to engine block, bearing clearances have a critical role. The existence of clearances allows the system to have impacts between components.

level2.p: The impact of clearance complicates the vibration of a system which is dominated by vibration at multiples of the half-order of crankshaft rotation frequency, and allows it to have intricate nonlinear vibrations.

The tangible results are the impact and self-excited vibration associated with rough “rumbling” noise. There are some measures proposed to optimize main bearing clearance. In some cases, peak noise level could be reduced through the efforts, but the signature of rumbling noise level remains the same. It had been shown that bearing clearance has no significant effect on impact-induced or parameter excited half-order noise. In some special situations, reducing clearance leads to the increase of noise, which could be due to oil film effects on bearing vibration.

p.span: Besides the crankshaft vibration, other types of sources could result in the rumble noise perceived in the passenger compartment. These include gas column resonance of the intake system, powertrain system torsional and bending resonance, non uniformity of combustion and the structural transmission, with carrier frequency of about 300 to

800 Hz (system natural frequency) and modulation frequency of 20 to 200 Hz. Usually the tuning of one part does not resolve rumble noise. Optimization of the following system could be effective to reduce rumble noise: the engine and transmission mount, driveshaft, exhaust hangers, intake and manifold system, exhaust pipes, and mufflers.

In general, the bearing itself does not generate a large noise. But the bearing has a significant effect on the supporting stiffness of the entire system and the system natural frequency. The bearing vibration results in resonance of the shaft system. Typically, sliding bearings experience less noise than roller bearings. For sliding bearings, the increase in bearing gap can significantly influence oil film pressure and the path of the shaft axis, and thus increases vibration and noise. For instance, some experiments show that a 30 µm increase of the bearing gap could increase engine noise by 3 dBA. The number of main bearings of the crankshaft has a significant effect on noise. Some experiments shows that when the number of main bearings of a four-stroke engine is changed from 5 to 3, the noise is increased by 2 to 3 dBA. For roller bearings, when loaded radically, the roller and case generate elastic deformation. In rotating operation, the shaft has periodic oscillatory motion, which allows the roller and case/fixture to generate impact. The structural and manufacturing accuracy has significant effect on bearing noise. In installation, the inaccuracy and compliance of the bearing bracket can create additional deformation

of bearing parts. Poor design and manufacturing tolerance of bearings causes deformation of the bearing inner ring. If the natural frequencies of the shaft system are close to the natural frequencies of the bearing, resonance is likely to occur. Moreover, contamination, damage, debris, wear, and corrosion have effects on bearing vibration and noise.

To suppress bearing noise, manufacturing accuracy and ring stiffness should be enhanced. Pretension can be used to reduce the gap. Tight control of assembly error and tolerance, use of a quality lubricant cream, and an improved seal can reduce bearing noise. Other approaches to reduce noise include enhancing manufacturing accuracy; ensuring smoothness and no defaults on all sliding/rolling interfaces; controlling dimensional accuracy of all parts; enhancing the accuracy and stiffness of the bearing bracket; and improving the application condition to reduce debris and corrosion. As an example, the following is a case of boom noise due to a four-stroke engine bearing. The four-stroke engine in the full acceleration process was perceived as having an intermittent boom noise. It is due to the instability caused by the interaction between coupled torsional-transverse vibrations of the crankshaft, and the bearing having a relatively larger radial gap. The recorded signal is processed to obtain the time-frequency spectrum of the boom noise, from which the magnitude of the dominant frequency component of the boom noise is illustrated with magnitude modulation. The magnitude

modulation is associated with the 0.5 and 1.5 order of shaft speed, whereas the noise frequency is independent of speed. It is believed that this boom noise is associated with the parameter excited vibration of the bearing.

The sources of the noise of the engine oil pumps include pressure pulsation, flow “ripple,” trapped oil within teeth, fluid-borne noise throughout the system, forces on the drive mechanism, and mechanical structure responses. The mechanical excitation sources and pressure pulsations are interactive. The pressure pulsation often produces mechanical noise of the drive mechanism. The pressure of the oil pump and mechanical forces are applied directly to the cover of the pump, which results in vibration radiating noise. Since the cover is usually relatively compliant, the vibration and radiated noise may be quite strong. The common types of oil pumps in engines include external gear pumps, gear rotor pumps and vane types. The noise mechanisms associated with engine oil pumps include: involute gear teeth and gear forces; oil transfer in tooth spaces on the periphery; low pressure being “dumped” to high; outlet flow having dynamic “ripple” or fluctuation; ripple decreasing with more teeth; flow ripple-created dynamic pressure; and oil trapped in meshing teeth. In the oil pump, oil is transferred around the periphery of the gears in the spaces between the teeth.

The oil is delivered to the outlet, or discharge, port in discrete “clumps,” producing flow variation or flow “ripple,” which gives rise to pressure variation due to the hydraulic impedance of the oil lubrication system down-stream of the pump. Impedance of the system is typically high enough to enable significant pressure ripple.

level2.p: Pressure ripple gives rise to dynamic forces which produce vibration and noise. Low-pressure oil from the inlet side could be “dumped” into the high pressure of the discharge port, causing a sudden pressure change. Metering grooves can be placed around the periphery of the gear teeth, connected to the discharge side. As a “pocket” of oil is moved from the inlet to the discharge, it encounters the grooves which allow a gradual buildup of oil pressure in the pocket so that its pressure is equal to the discharge pressure when it reaches the discharge side. Pressure relief grooves are used to allow trapped oil in the tooth mesh to escape to either the inlet or discharge side. These grooves do not allow a direct leak from discharge to inlet. Without this pressure relief, trapped oil can cause shock and cavitation. Increasing tooth count can divide oil delivery into smaller “pockets” with smaller flow variation.

p.span: Thus the pressure ripple and noise is reduced. The split gear pump reduces ripple by a similar mechanism to increased tooth count, without actually adding teeth. The generator oil pump is an internal/external gear arrangement, with very compact geometry. The gear teeth are not involutes. Tips of the

inner gear teeth seal against the outer gear to form pockets. As the gears rotate, the pockets expand and contract, with a volume that varies approximately sinusoidal. The expanding pockets are placed over the oil inlet cavity.

level2.p: They “pull” oil from the inlet as they expand. The contracting pockets are placed over the discharge cavity. They “push” oil into it as they contract. The flow from each pocket combines to produce the total flow of the pump, with harmonics at multiples of N + 1 order of the outer gear.

p.span: With odd number of pockets, the fundamental order of the total pressure, at N + 1 order, is zero amplitude. As such, the total waveform does not show any periodic behavior at N + 1 pulses per revolution. The 2nd harmonic order (2N + 2) is the largest harmonic component. The inner gear drive frequency is usually used as the reference for representing pump orders. Flow harmonics exist at multiples of N + 1 order of outer gear frequency. The outer gear turns at N/(N + l) times the speed of the inner gear. Therefore, N + 1 order of the outer gear is N order of the inner gear. The flow harmonics are present at multiples of the N + 1 order of the inner gear drive frequency. However, this relationship is only valid for the precise flow waveform of the half-sine wave. The flow in actual pump applications are modified by backflow and trapped oil, thus minimizing the benefit which might be achieved with an odd number of pockets. It is still a good design

practice to use an odd number of pockets. When low-pressure oil from the inlet port is delivered to the high-pressure discharge port, oil from the discharge port compresses it and causes a backflow pulse.

The pulse occurs for every pocket, N + 1 times per revolution. The backflow pulse may modify flow waveform significantly. An N + 1 order, large variation could be introduced. For an odd number of pockets, as in the example, the N + 1 order is reintroduced where it was completely absent. Variation of the total flow waveform can be greatly increased. A certain amount of back flow is almost always present in practice. Timing and metering grooves allow controlled backflow, which assists the pre-compression from delayed discharge port timing. It is somewhat self regulating, as higher pressures will create more backflow, as is desired for the higher pressure. Quiet oil pumps should be designed to minimize the noise sources associated with pressure ripple and drive mechanism forces. It is also important to control the structural vibration path from the sources to the noise-radiating surfaces of the engine. The integral front cover pump has a very sensitive noise transfer path. Reductions in pump noise can be achieved by isolating the pump from the radiating surfaces. Large noise reductions can be achieved throughout the operating range of the pump. The following experimental facts are helpful for the pump design: timing and metering grooves can attain optimum at specific speeds, pressures, and air

ntrainment; speed determines the time available for backflow and suction; discharge pressure determines the force acting on the back flow; as speed increases, the relationship of noise and pressure will change.

level2.p: The timing chain has been applied in camshaft transmission due to its advantageous attributes such as wear durability and high strength, particularly in the high-performance engine. The major excitation components of chain noise are meshing impact and polygonal effects. The meshing frequency depends on the tooth number of the chain sprocket and shaft rotating speed.

The most popular chain noise is whine noise, which depends on the meshing impact force and the vibration response of engine components and system such as the engine front cover and the cover of the camshaft. The polygonal effect causes elevation and drop of the chain element and thus leads to the transverse and torsional vibration of the chain as well as speed variation. The impact noise of the roller generated in roller-sprocket meshing is the dominant component of chain noise. The axial and torsional vibrations could couple with transverse vibrations, thus exaggerating the transverse vibration and noise radiation. The transverse vibration of the belt can be modeled using a string model. The transverse vibration of the short belt can be modeled using a beam model. In applications, the approaches to controlling timing tooth belt noise include optimization of belt and sprocket to minimize meshing impact, and optimization of system design such as tension and load distribution. Some of the approaches are similar to that for gear noise control, such as the use of optimal tooth parameters and structures.

The transmission controls the torque-speed relationship for the powertrain. It consists of various gearing structures, shafts, and bearings. Helical gears are used for manual transmissions and planetary gears are used for automatic transmissions. Transmission

noises can be separated into two groups. The first group represents transmission noises resulting from gears engaged in the torque flow or meshing noise, the second group includes noises from unloaded transmission components such as loose gears or synchronizer rings bouncing inside their functional backlashes and clearances [61].

level2.p: Transmission whine is the most-occurring transmission noise, which is in the high frequency range (2 kHz–15 kHz). This is due to the meshing of teeth. As torque is transmitted through these teeth, they will deform, leading to variation between the designed profile that kinematics requires and the actual profile due to deformation.

This is referred to as transmission error and is known to be the root cause of many transmission noises. If a pair of gears is perfectly connected, the following conditions must be satisfied for both gears: the gear circles are geometrically perfect; the gears are perfectly aligned; the gears are infinitely stiff. p.span: The transmission error can be found wherever gear meshing exists, such as in the transmission, front

and rear axles, and transfer case. The transmission error causes meshing excitation, which could result in the bending and torsional vibration of the driveshaft that is transferred to the body through mounts and bearings. The excitation frequency of gear meshing is the product of the first order of the driveline excitation and the numbers of teeth in the driving pinion of the axle.

To reduce the excitation caused by transmission error, gear teeth and the gear meshing should be optimally designed. The modal separation between driveshafts’ bending and torsional modes also helps reduce the excitation. Transmission error (TE) could be due to the poor design, manufacturing tolerance, wear and degradation, tooth mesh stiffness variation, and impacts (engagement and separation). It can also be due to change of mesh force direction, friction, air and lubricant entrapment, gear tooth geometry, and gear train dynamics. Gear whine is a typical noise due to TE, and is characterized as a tonal noise with specific frequency. System resonance could occur when the excitation frequency from the gear pair coincides with the resonance of the system, which may include the individual or coupled torsional, lateral, and axial motion. The mechanism of whine is the meshing excitation-induced torsional vibration and transverse vibration of gear shaft and the system resonance. This further magnifies dynamic meshing and load, resulting in the interaction between bearing and gear box, and finally causing the gear box and

related components to radiate noise. A characteristic of gear transmission is that the meshing point has both rolling motion and sliding motion. The interaction between teeth generate the inevitable impact and friction, thus create meshing vibration and noise, which are dependent on rotating speed. The meshing frequency is given by f ≈ nN/60, in which N is the number of gear tooth, n is the gear rotating speed (RPM).

Transmission whine is primarily generated by transmission error, which is a deviation of the meshing gears from a perfectly conjugate (smooth) motion due to manufacturing tolerances, tooth corrections, and elastic deflection due to transmitted torque. The transmission error excites the geared shaft and bearing system, leading to dynamic forces at the bearings, which, in turn, excite the transmission casing, causing it to radiate noise. Gear whine can be reduced through a combination of gear parameter optimization and manufacturing process tolerance control directed at reducing the effective transmission error. The process of gear selection and profile modification design is facilitated by evaluating details of the tooth contact analysis through the roll angle, including the effect of gear tooth, gear blank, and shaft deflections under load. The factors influencing gear noise include gear tooth geometric parameters, the accuracy and smoothness of the gear, the structure and profile of other gear factors, shaft stiffness, and lubricant. The abatement approach of gear noise includes:

apply gear materials with high inner damping, or isolation design; optimization of gear parameters and structures; enhance manufacturing accuracy of gear; edge treatment; and system dynamics control to increase damping. Transmission whine occurs (and is probably expected) for most vehicles when they are in reverse. Low gear whine in partial throttle conditions occurs frequently and is annoying to the drivers. In addition, slowing the vehicle by only friction (no gas or brake) will expose the transmission whine problem.

level2.p: Vehicle gear meshing noise control usually is implemented through two approaches: one is to reduce transmission errors by optimizing tooth profile and enhancing manufacturing accuracy; the second is to control system dynamics, which can be implemented by modifying the gear/transmission system design.

p.span: The impact noise of the wideband spectrum of gear called rattle is due to the impact of gears with slash gap. The onset of impacts from an unloaded gear pair is more likely to occur than from an engaged set. Transmission rattle is caused by engine excitation and backlash in geared transaxles. Backlash yields piecewise nonlinear characteristics in gear mesh stiffness.
shows the occurrence of gear slash gap. This slash can create impact, nonlinear

vibration, and noise. The variation of the period load of the gear and poor tolerance worsen this dynamic impact load. This dynamic load can deform the shaft and generate extra bearing load. The dynamic bearing load can transmit to the transmission case and engine block/cover, allowing the shell/plate structure to radiate noise. Gear rattle could be caused by torsional vibrations of the crankshaft due to the engine firing excitation and inertial imbalance, which initiates cyclic angular vibration that is transmitted from the engine to the transmission input shaft, leading to impacts of gear and gear teeth oscillation within their backlash. The gear vibrations are finally transmitted via the supporting bearings to the transmission case, which radiates noise to the air.
Gear backlash.

The angular velocity fluctuations causing the gear rattle are mainly due to the engine firing order. The amplitude of the angular crankshaft accelerations depends on the number of cylinders, cycles, and the type of fuel (gasoline or diesel). As an example, for a four-stroke, four-cylinder engine, the torque engine fluctuation will mainly oscillate with twice the frequency of the crank rotational frequency. Although

the excitation itself occurs in a well-defined range of low frequencies, the measured rattle noise has a broadband distribution: from 1 kHz to 8 kHz. The measurable rattling noise in the surrounding area of the transmission consists of a broadband frequency spectrum ranging from 1–6 kHz. The torsional vibrations excite idle components, such as idler gears, synchronizer rings, and sliding sleeves to vibrate within their functional clearances. Gear rattle is strongly audible inside the vehicle cabin during the run-up at low speed and high load, or with the transmission in neutral and the clutch engaged (drive rattle or idle rattle).

Transmission noise reduction may be obtained in different ways: 1. reducing the exciting source or torsional vibrations; 2. optimizing the design parameters; 3. increasing the vehicle damping characteristics. Usually the third possibility is more complex and economically less advantageous than the others. Manual transmission gear rattle could occur when the transmission system’s torsional resonance is excited by the firing order. The unloaded pair could have impact that results in rattle, which is transmitted to the transmission housing through the shaft bearing.

shows various approaches used to damper torsional vibrations of the transmission system. Besides whine and rattle, there are other types of noise in transmissions. The sliding friction between meshing teeth is one of the primary excitations for noise and vibration in geared systems. Existing research suggests that the measured

maximum friction coefficients are in the range of 0.05 to 0.06, subject to load. Friction coefficients increase at low sliding speeds. The reversal of sliding which occurs at the pitch-point does not cause a discontinuity in the friction coefficient, which shows a smooth transition as the friction force reverses direction. The sliding friction has been recognized as a significant source of noise and vibration in gear meshing. It was found that the dynamic friction force could be the same order of magnitude as the forces normal to the tooth profile for certain cases.
Various approaches to dampen torsional vibrations.

Friction forces play an important role in load transmitted to the bearing and housing in gear meshing, particularly at high torque and low speed. Friction has a predominant effect at higher harmonics of meshing frequency. Both oil viscosity and surface
roughness had a large influence on the vibro acoustic behavior.

level2.p: A variety of clutches have been extensively used in passenger cars for engaging different gears in automatic transmissions. The clutch system could be excited by torsional and axial flywheel vibrations, which are influenced by engine firing orders. There are many vibrations and noise phenomena associated with the clutch system, just to name a few: whoop, tingling, toc-toc, chatter, shuffle, clunk, judder, shudder, and squeal. Whoop is a tactile foot vibration accompanied by noise. The clutch whoop could occur when the clutch is engaging or disengaging.

p.span: It causes low-frequency vibrations of the clutch pedal and it also results in noise. Tingling is a strong pedal vibration that is associated with engine harmonic orders. Toc-toc is low-frequency vibration of the pedal that is associated with a half-order that is perceived by the foot. The clutch phenomena depend on engine speed, pedal position and actuation speed, temperature of wet clutch, and wear.

illustrates sources of excitation of clutch pedal vibration. The axial vibration of the flywheel due to engine combustion excitation and crankshaft compliance can be transmitted to the clutch, which further induces the clutch pedal vibration that is perceived by the driver’s foot. The alignment of the
release bearing and powertrain vibration also contribute to it.
Clutch vibrations.

level3.p: The chatter could occur when a periodic torque change is created in the sliding clutch, and is perceived as both vibrations and noise. It could be due to friction-induced vibrations. The clunk of metal impact noise could occur due to rapid clutch engagement or gear shifting.

p.span: Driveline clunk is a phenomenon that can adversely affect customer perception of vehicle quality. Clunk is created by the impact of two driveline components as they oscillate in response to a torque disturbance in the driveline system. This disturbance is typically caused by an engine torque variation, most severely through a throttle or clutch manipulation. This torque variation excites a torsional vibration from the driveline, amplified by a variety of mechanisms such as resonances of various

shafts, housings and axles, clutch oscillations, and gear impacts. Because automotive drivelines are complex systems composed of many rotating components, it is difficult to identify the impacts that cause clunk and evaluate the significant parameters that can affect these phenomena. In the following paragraphs we discuss friction-induced vibration of the clutch. In starting engagement, the friction clutch is likely to generate judder, which is a low-frequency, friction-induced torsional vibration of the driveline. It affects starting smoothness and ride comfort. It is due to the decreasing friction of the clutch with respect to the slip speed between the flywheel and friction disk. Sometimes misalignment of the driveline also contributes to it. Take-off clutch judder is another low-frequency vibration of the fore-and-aft type in the frequency range of 5–20 Hz or even higher, due to the torsional vibration of the driveline that occurs during the clutch engagement process. Clutch judder generally has two root causes: a particular type of the friction-sliding speed curve and misalignment in the driveline.

The beat phenomena and variation in torque-time traces have been observed. It is also noted that clutch judder is affected considerably by the buildup time of the axial load and the friction sliding speed variation of the facing. Judder is a type of self-excited vibration of the vehicle driveline, whose frequency is independent of shaft revolution speeds. The vibration could be transmitted to the vehicle body through the suspension mount and engine mount. For instance, a

front-engine, rear-drive vehicle judder could be close to the third mode of driveline torsional vibration. The countermeasure is to improve the clutch friction characteristics and the damping of the driveline system. This will be further elaborated at the end of this section. Clutch operation or engagement is usually attained through friction effects between driving and driven ends, in which self-excited vibrations could be triggered for some of the system with improper friction properties and system combinations. Low-frequency torsional vibrations of powertrain called shudder (judder) occasionally occurs due to clutch friction during acceleration at low speed. Shudder could exist in dry clutches in a manual transmission or in wet clutches in an automatic transmission. Squeal noise could even occur in dry clutch applications. The slippage of the torque converter clutch can excite a low-frequency torsional response of the entire powertrain due to the property of velocity-dependent friction. The shudder severity varies with clutch surface characteristics, temperature, lubrication additives, and vehicle operating conditions.

It has been found that some combination of clutch design and transmission fluid can prevent negative damping associated with velocity-dependent friction. On the other hand, some attenuation of problem severity can be obtained with increased damping in the clutch or the torque converter damper. Most wet-clutch-related vibrations are attributed to the velocity-dependence properties of friction. A problem area in most wet clutches working at low

velocity is the occurrence of shudder associated with the negative slope of the friction-velocity property of the lubricated interface. The anti-shudder performance of automatic transmissions has been of primary interest in new designs featuring lockup and continuous-slip torque converter clutches. Generally stick-slip occurs at low velocities when the static coefficient of friction is higher than the dynamic coefficient of friction. Friction-induced instability takes place at higher sliding velocities due to a negative slope of the friction vs. velocity curve. The influence of the velocity-dependent friction on the anti-shudder performance of wet clutches has been documented. A friction-velocity curve with positive slope is usually considered to be an advantage, but neither a necessary nor sufficient condition to guarantee stability. It was concluded that factors such as level of friction, engine speed, and engine torque-speed slope also affect the dynamic behavior of the system. It was found that fluidrelated factors such as level of friction, friction-velocity characteristics, and friction-pressure characteristics should be optimized to improve the overall performance of the clutch.

shows a typical coefficient of friction of automotive transmission fluid (ATF) with and without additives, which is a key factor influencing system vibrations. Two values called μ1/μ50 and μ100/ μ300 can be used as indexes for evaluation of the friction property, where μ1 is the coefficient of friction at 1 rpm, and so on. In this case the first ratio is the

anti-shudder performance at low sliding velocities, and the second is the anti shudder performance at higher sliding velocities. Values of these ratios larger than 1 may correspond to observed vibrations in vehicles. There are several other factors used as a friction indicator of the potential for frictionally induced vibrations. Another extension includes the ratio μ1/μ20, where μ1 and μ20 are the coefficient of friction at sliding velocities of 1 and 20 cm/s, respectively. The coefficient of friction of the clutch is strongly temperature dependent. This influence of temperature on friction is because of the fact that temperature affects both fluid viscosity as well as the formation of tribo layers. The surface active additives in the transmission fluid present at the sliding interfaces in the clutch, which have a significant effect on friction. The rate of generation of the tribo layer is influenced by the temperature-dependent surface activity. In addition, the surface temperature will also determine which types of additives will dominate in the tribo layer. It has been shown that static and dynamic coefficients of friction decrease
with increasing temperature. Moreover, the change rates of static friction and dynamic friction due to increased additives or due to temperature change could be different.
Coefficient of friction.

This rate of change differed between static and dynamic friction and may, therefore, alter the anti shudder properties. Thus a fluid with good anti-shudder properties at high temperatures may have very poor properties at low temperatures, as seen in

. Some vibration and noise problems associated with the dry friction clutch are attributed to mode-coupling-type self-excited vibrations. During the engagement of the dry friction clutch in manual transmissions, a strong squealing noise could occur. For this case, in near full engagement the pressure plate suddenly starts vibrating with a frequency close to the first natural frequency of the rotational subsystem. This problem exhibits typical signs of a dynamic instability associated with a constant friction coefficient. It was observed that the instability of the rigid-body wobbling mode is controlled by the friction forces, and this mode is also affected by the first bending mode of the pressure plate. A stiffer plate could lead to a design with a reduced tendency to the squeal noise. It has been demonstrated that there exists potential mode-coupling between the pressure-plate wobbling mode and the first elastic deformation mode of the pressure plate. The stability threshold depends on the friction coefficient, the pressure plate geometry, and structural stiffness. Two conditions were observed to generate the transient squeal noise.
First, the engine speed is within the 1500–2500 RPM range, and the slip speed is relatively high. A constant coefficient of friction μ corresponding to the threshold of noise may be assumed.

level3.p: This allows noise to not follow the mechanism of classical stick-slip. Second, the clutch pedal motion is in the condition that the clutch is close to full engagement. Measurements of noise spectra exhibit a dominant frequency around 450 Hz. This frequency has been correlated to the wobbling rigid-body motion of the pressure plate (both out-of-plane rotations) from dynamometer tests and the simple math model. The pressure plate and the disk cushion are assumed to be the main components that control the squeal phenomenon. In order to consider the nonlinear characteristic of the cushion, a mathematical modeling yields an asymmetric stiffness matrix characterized by the coefficient of friction and stiffness ratio. The results of complex eigenvalue analysis are in agreement with experimental observations. It is seen that the instability of the rigid-body wobbling mode is controlled by the friction forces. This mode may, however, be also affected by the first bending mode of the pressure plate. Therefore, a stiffer plate could lead to a design with a reduced tendency to squeal.

p.span: In an engine air intake system, intake noise radiates from the inlet or the open end. The reduction

of intake noise is critical for reducing vehicle interior noise and pass-by noise, and for enhancing interior sound quality to meet customer expectations. Conventionally, priority of intake system design has been the engine volumetric efficiency. More and more efforts have been made for intake system design to attain a lower noise target.
A typical air intake system consists of a dirty side tube, an expansion chamber (normally the air cleaner box), and a clean side duct.

is a schematic of an automotive engine intake system. It consists of an engine manifold system and an air intake system. The engine manifold system includes manifolds and a surge tank. The air intake system consists of throttle valve, idle intake pipe, flexible connecter, clean air duct, quarter wave pipe, air cleaner box, filter, Helmholtz resonator, and dirty side tube (inlet).
Coefficient of friction vs temperature.
The basic need of an intake system design is to allow it to have higher engine volumetric efficiency. If an engine has no intake system, the pressure at the

throttle valve is ambient pressure; however, after an intake system is applied, the pressure at the throttle valve is higher than the ambient pressure. The difference between the higher pressure due to the application of the intake system and the ambient pressure is known as back-pressure. The existence of back-pressure allows part of the engine’s power to be wasted. The larger the cross-section area of the intake duct, the smaller the engine power loss. On the other hand, the smaller the cross-section area of the intake duct, the less the noise radiated from the intake system. Therefore, there is a conflict between the requirements of low power loss and low noise on the cross section area of the intake duct. A trade-off is needed in real designs. In addition to the requirements of the low power loss and low noise, there are other requirements for intake system design, which include water-proof and snow-proof considerations as well as vibration reductions.

One-dimensional linear acoustic models have been widely used for the evaluation of noise performance of intake and exhaust systems, due to their simplicity and low computational requirements in the description of complex geometries. In the engine’s operation, the intake system works intermittently to allow fresh air to flow into the engine. The interrupted air-flow from the opening and closing of the intake valve gives rise to impulsive pressure variation. This pressure pulse propagates to the intake inlet, leading to sound radiation.
shows the typical pressure pulse measured from the intake
valve of a cylinder of a four-stroke engine. The waveform repeats once every two crank revolutions, or 720° crank degrees.
Automotive intake system.

is the spectrum representation of the pulse pressure with respect to crank order. The pressure pulse exhibits a series of spectrum lines located at the harmonics of 1/2 crank order. The higher the order, the smaller the magnitude of the spectrum line. For multiple-cylinder situations, the total sound is the sum of the sound from each cylinder
traveling along the system to the location where they are measured.

level2.p: Certain special volumetric devices called silencers (mufflers) are capable of abating tonal or narrow-band noise of specific frequencies in the induction system. The silencers are special ducts, pipes, or openings/cavities which accommodate the free flow of air while impeding the transmission of sound. There are two types of silencers, resonant (reactive) and resistive.

p.span: Reactive silencers include the side branch resonator (Helmholtz type of resonator or quarter wave tuner) and expansion chamber. Reactive silencers rely on the mechanism of expansion, contraction, or pipe protrusion to abate noise. The abrupt expansions or contractions of air flow allow the discontinuity which generates reflective sound waves that could result in the attenuation of the
incident waves, and thus gives rise to a radiation of smaller sound waves.

The reflection of acoustic waves at the discontinuities, and the interaction of these waves, can reduce the transmission of sound. The duct with a closed end acting as an acoustic oscillator could result in some attenuation to incident waves. The reactive silencer can be designed to have a high attenuation in a specific frequency band. The Helmholtz resonator is a type of silencer that has a specified chamber and is widely used to abate noise at specific lower frequencies. Its working principle is similar to the vibration dynamic absorber. The air in the chamber serves as a spring, and the mass of the air in the chamber reacts as a spring to form a harmonic oscillator system. Upon a change in the volume of the air chamber, the silencer can shift the frequency of the resonance. A quarter wave tuner is similar to a Helmholtz resonator in principle. The expansion chamber is another type of silencer, such as a cleaner box, that serves as a cleaning component as well as a silencer. Resistive or dissipative silencers are made by special ducts, pipes, openings/ cavities, or chambers with the inside walls lined with acoustically absorptive material, which allow for the free flow of air on the surface while impeding the transmission of sound. They attenuate sound by the acoustic energy-absorbing action of absorptive material within the silencers. This type of device typically provides noise attenuation over a broad frequency range. Intake noise is a major noise source of a vehicle. In addition to the flow-pulse
induced intake noise, the poor structure design of the intake system with insufficient stiffness also leads to structural radiated noise.

The reduction of the intake system noise can significantly reduce vehicle interior noise and pass-by noise. Control of intake system acoustic performance helps to tune interior sound quality. The first design parameter for intake system noise attenuation is the silencing volume, which is usually referred to as the sum of the volumes of the air clean box and Helmholtz silencer. Generally, the larger the silencing volume, the better the noise reduction performance. For the expansion silencer, the larger the volume, the larger the transmission loss of noise, and the wider the frequency band for noise abating. For the Helmholtz silencer, the larger the volume, the lower the frequency limit for noise attenuation. For four- and six-cylinder engines, the volumes of silencing components are usually required up to 10 to 15 liters.
lists

the silencing volumes of some vehicles’ engines. The second parameter for intake system noise control is the cross-section area of the duct. The smaller the cross-section area of the duct, the larger the expansion ratio of the expansion silencer, and therefore the larger the transmission loss and the better the silencing effects. However, the smaller cross-section area of the duct results in higher back pressure and air friction noise. The third parameter for intake system design to abate noise is the location of the intake orifice. As a noise source, it should be kept away from the compartment. The real location of the intake orifice is also subject to the constraints required to prevent water and snow entry and allow efficient flow of air.

p.span: The noise and vibration transmission paths from external excitation to the vehicle compartment interior include door/quarter panels, floor, roof, dash, door window strip, glass window strip, glass, vents and ducts, engine/transmission, mounts, exhaust hangers, suspension, control cables, body structural resonances, and cavity acoustic resonances, among others. There exist many excitations to the body, which include the imbalanced dynamic force in tire/wheel, road excitation, impact due to engine combustion, rotating and reciprocal inertia force and torque of engine, as well as the motions of other systems. These excitations and responses transmit to the body in a direct or indirect way, which causes body structure vibration that radiates noise into the

compartment. The compartment noise due to this type of mechanism is referred to as structure-borne noise. For instance, a typical structure-borne noise is the boom either due to engine excitation associated with engine firing or due to powertrain bending resonance driven by the engine and reciprocating unbalance. Other examples of structure-borne noise include moan and rumble of the interior due to the powertrain, driveline, or even the exhaust system’s bending resonance. For the passenger car, its major frequency ranges from tens of hertz to several hundred hertz, or even higher.

In contrast to the structure-borne noise, airborne noise is referred to as the compartment interior noise transmitted into the interior through openings or orifices from the noise sources outside of the body, which include tire/road noise and powertrain noise. The compartment airborne noise usually ranges from several hundred to several thousand hertz, or even higher. For example, typical airborne noises include the whine and rattle from transmission noise, the whine from the alternator, hoot from the intake system, hum from the fuel pump, knocking from engine piston/bearings, ticking from valves or the engine, and axle noise from gear teeth [1–13]. Vehicle body design is critical for the abatement of structure-borne noise. The body structure design is usually evaluated in terms of the sensitivity or the response characteristics of structural vibrations and noise of the body with respect to the specific point excitations. Good performance of bodies involves

smaller vibrations and noise responses to excitation, or smaller sensitivity. The second session of this chapter discusses the vibration and sound response characteristics of the body, and its damping control and design. Many body structures with separated frames make use of a series of body mounts to connect with the frame, and therefore the force transmitted to the body from the frame could be decayed by the mounts. A body mount consists of a cushion for vehicle vibration isolation. For the loaded type of body, the front and rear frames may either connect with the body through mounts or connect with body rigidly [14].

There are many factors influencing the design of the connection between the frame and body; they include handling performance, a gap between the chassis and road, cost control, etc. Sometimes, vibration isolation in the low-frequency range must be considered. In principle, the rigid connection between a frame and body is helpful to enhance the mode frequencies of the overall vehicle and improve mode shapes. On the other hand, the rigid connection directly affects the transmission of high frequency vibrations and noise [15]. Compared with the body of an unloaded type or separated type, the body of a loaded type or integrated type with a rigid connection with the frame sacrifices a cushion for vibration isolation [16]. The excitation force of the engine undergoes a large attenuation after it is transmitted to the frame or sub frame through the mounts [17]. Similarly, the rear differentiator of the vehicle with

a loaded-type body is usually installed on the rear sub frame through mounts. The alternator/generator, water pump, oil pump, and air compressor are usually connected to the engine body through supporting brackets, where mounts are also occasionally used. The supporting bracket design is crucial for vibration reduction of these cases. Regardless of the methods of connection and types of isolation, one of the most critical issues to address concerning the entire vehicle’s structural vibrations and noise is the isolation effect at the connecting points, or the attenuation of excitation transmission [18].

level2.p: There are many excitations leading to vehicle structural vibrations and noise. These excitations are located in different places in a vehicle and vary with the vehicle operating conditions. The excitation with a large magnitude does not necessarily cause significant vehicle structural vibrations and noise. On the other hand, the excitation with a small magnitude does not mean it can be ignored. For instance, the magnitude of engine excitation is large. However, if isolation is proper, it does not cause serious vehicle structural vibrations and noise. For some systems such as the exhaust system, if its connection with the body is poorly designed, and the connection point is close to a vibration-sensitive location on the body, even a small excitation could result in significant structural vibrations and noise problems of the vehicle. In the following section, we discuss the characteristics of the excitations of various sources and the design procedures for their attenuation [19].

p.span: The body structures of typical passenger cars are usually formed by welding multiple stamped steel plates of thickness of 0.7 to 1 mm.

Transfer function of panel.

In the acceptance response transfer function of a typical plate, the peaks on the curve indicate several low-order natural modes [21]. The first- and second-order mode shapes of a rectangular plate are illustrated in
. The first-order shape exhibits in-phase vibration of the entire area without node and node line. The second-order shape exhibits out-of-phase vibrations at two areas with one node line in between.
First (a) and second (b) order mode shape of a rectangular plate supported simply at four sides.

level3.p: For the same plate, if four sides are fixed, the first-order frequency is higher than that of the simply supported case, but the first-order mode shape is similar to that of the simply supported case [22].

The real boundary condition of the plate on the vehicle body is neither the simply supported nor the fixed. The actual first-order natural frequency of the plate on the vehicle body is usually between the estimated values from the simply supported case and fixed case, respectively. The plates on the vehicle body usually need local stiffness strengthening by adding extra plates or beams, or being stamped with corrugated shapes or other complex treatment to attain the effect of local stiffness strengthening. The modal frequencies and modal shapes of complex plates are usually obtained by using the finite element method or real testing [23].

p.span: The modal frequencies corresponding to the peaks on the spectrum of acceptance are dependent on mode stiffness and mode mass, whereas the peaks depend on mode damping. If a specific mode frequency must be increased, the usual approach is to increase stiffness. In the trials to increase local

structure stiffness for enhancing the natural frequency, the effect of mode shape and the interaction needs to be considered. For instance, for the first-order mode shape of a cantilever beam, the effect on natural frequency is strong when the stiffness is locally increased at the location close to the support location. When the stiffness is locally increased at a place far from the support location, it has a very small effect on enhancing the specific mode frequency. Next, we discuss the acoustic modes of the vehicle compartment [24].

Air as an elastic medium within the enclosure of the compartment forms numerous vibration modes, or acoustic modes. The first mode frequency is usually in the range between 40 and 80 Hz. The acoustic modes of low frequency can be obtained by using the finite element method.

Unlike the structures of plates and beams, the mode frequency density of the acoustic mode is proportional to the cube of frequency. The mode density increases rapidly with increase of frequency. For instance, for a compartment with an interior volume of 3.6 cubic meters, the mode numbers within the bandwidth of 100 Hz centered at 1000 Hz are as high as 13. When the mode density reaches a certain high level, the calculation cost is too high to be conducted by using the finite element method. Moreover, when mode density reaches a certain high level, the vibration and sound problem is no longer a deterministic problem with certainty; instead, it is a nondeterministic problem having statistical characteristics. Therefore, the statistical approach must be used to quantify and characterize [26]. In the above acoustic mode analysis, the wall of the compartment is assumed to be rigid and the structural vibration of

the body is not considered. In fact, in the frequency range of the low-order acoustic mode, the acoustic mode of the compartment and the structural modes of the body have strong coupling; thus for the calculation of acoustic modes the effect of structure vibration must be considered, and vice versa. In other words, the analysis and calculation of body structure vibrations and acoustic modes should be done simultaneously as a coupled system. The strong coupling between air in the compartment and the compartment structure at low frequency comes from the confinement of the compartment enclosure [27].
If the air in the confined enclosure is compressed, it creates a pure volume change and exhibits high impedance, which is likely to cause strong coupling with body structure vibrations.

illustrates the out-of-phase change of mode shape in the rear roof and floor of the body. It creates pure volume change, and thus has strong coupling with the air inside the compartment. The mode frequency of this coupled system may be close to the first-order natural frequency of the acoustic mode, or may be obviously lower than it. Under the excitations of the vehicle such as the powertrain excitation, if the response of this low-frequency coupled mode is high enough, it creates significant pulsation of sound pressure, and causes hearing discomfort, and a dizzy and nauseated feeling. This perceived uncomfortable sound is usually called boom [28].
Out-of-phase mode shapes of the roof and rear floor of the body structure.

level3.p: Experience indicates that when a vehicle window is slightly opened, the boom can be reduced substantially. This is due to the fact that opening the window eliminates the confinement of air in the compartment, and thus reduces air impedance and reduces the coupling between structural vibrations and acoustic modes.

p.span: However, this cannot be used as the solution to the problem. In vehicle design, the main solution to the boom is to identify the excitation source, and reduce the excitation and transmission. Body boom is likely to occur at engine idle or acceleration states; thus, reducing the related engine excitation is crucial. A vehicle traveling on rough roads or under uneven/bump excitation is also likely to have boom. In the automotive industry, there were many efforts made to modify body structures to reduce boom, including those to add extra mass on the rear roof, change the roof and other interior trim/panels, change the configuration of the seats, add a damping layer on

the rear roof and floor, improve the rear door structure, and increase the stiffness of the seal of the rear windows. However, most of these approaches are not effective, as these tuning approaches are local changes, which do not enhance overall structure stiffness sufficiently [29]. These approaches do not substantially change the coupling between the acoustic mode and structural vibrations. Sometimes, adding ribs in the proper location in the roof has some effect to reduce boom. Usually, the abatement of boom by using structure modification needs guideline from analysis and calculation by using finite element analysis, otherwise the change could worsen the problem, or introduces another vibration and noise problem. Another effective approach to resolve boom is to use an active control system for vibration and noise control [30].

There are many origins of booming noise in a vehicle when excitation frequency coincides with the compartment acoustic resonance: engine and drivetrain excitation, excessive radiation from intake/exhaust systems, road excitation, and wind fluctuation are some of them. The road boom appears at a certain speed of the vehicle when a part of the body panels or compartment severely responds to the road excitation. The air buffeting appears at vehicle speeds at which the passenger compartment responds in a feedback way to the flow fluctuation at the opening of a window or sunroof. The powertrain boom consists predominantly of pure or narrow-band tones related to the fundamental firing frequency

of the engine and its harmonics. The booming sound from the intake or exhaust system also has similar characteristics with the powertrain boom. The strength of the coupling between the acoustic mode and vehicle vibration modes decreases with the increase of vibration frequency [31]. At sufficiently high frequency, the vibrations of each plate basically do not interact with nearby plates soldered on the same beam. The vibrations of each plate can be treated independently. Then the radiation coefficient of the plate can be used to evaluate the coupling between the plate vibrations and acoustic enclosure. The radiation of the plate can be developed using the concept of wave. Consider a uniform plate structure under vertical excitation; elastic bending waves create and propagate in the plates. The velocity of the elastic bending wave cb is dependent on structure materials and geometry attributes. It is also a function of frequency.

plots the wave velocity of the elastic bending wave as a function of 1/3 octave frequency for a vehicle plate of thickness 0.8 mm. When the frequency increases by two octaves, the wave velocity increases by 100%. For comparison purposes, the wave velocity of the acoustic wave of air is also plotted in the same figure, which is a horizontal line [32]. In the range below several thousand hertz, the velocity of the elastic bending wave is much lower than that of air. The velocity of the elastic bending wave increases with the increase of frequency, and exceeds the wave velocity of air at some critical frequency called

“match frequency.” When the vibration frequency is higher than the match frequency, the velocity of the elastic bending wave of the plate is higher than that of air, leading to the strong coupling of the two waves, and thus the greatly increased sound radiation coefficient of plate vibration.
Wave velocity.

level3.p: The concept of the sound radiation coefficient of plates helps to relate structural vibrations with structural sound quantitatively. Usually the plates on a vehicle body have different sound radiation coefficients. If a vehicle body has many plates whose vibration velocity magnitudes are close, then the priority of noise control is to control the vibrations of the plates that have larger sound radiation coefficients. The efficient way to reduce larger sound radiation coefficients of plates is by damping treatment.

Damping characterizes the attenuation capability of a structure to its vibration response or energy. The higher the damping, the larger the capability of the system to attenuate its vibrations. Damping ratio and damping loss factor are used to quantify system damping. Damping ratio is used to characterize the decay of the vibration magnitude; loss factor is used to characterize energy decay. The loss factor is two times the damping ratio. The damping loss factor of a body steel plate is in the range of 0.0005–0.001. When multiple plates are used to form the floor or doors by using the process of stamping, welding, and rivet, the structure vibrations cause local frictions in interfaces close to welding and rivet points, which gives rise to extra damping. The measured damping of plates on the vehicle body could be much higher than their unassembled case. The damping loss factor could be as high as 0.005 or even higher. Interior trim and seals can also increase the structural damping of a body. The actual damping of the body structure is usually obviously higher than that of the plate before it is assembled. On the other hand, the plate structures used for the body usually undergo special surface damping treatment before assembly to enhance damping [34].

p.span: The treatment of vehicle body structure damping usually involves two kinds: the free damping layer treatment and the constraint damping layer
treatment, as shown in

. In the structure with the free damping layer, a free damping layer is sprayed or attached on the surface of a steel plate. In vibrations, the elastic bending vibrations cause the compressive and extensive strain of the damping layer, and the viscous compressive effect of the damping layer dissipates vibration energy and converts part of the plate vibration energy into thermal energy. The damping layer is usually thicker than that of the base plate. The constraint damping treated plates are usually called switched damping structure, which consists of the base plate, a layer of viscous damping, and a layer of constraint. In the switched damping structure, the elastic bending vibrations of plates cause compressive and extensive strain of the damping layer; the damping layer undergoes much more severe shear strain due to the constraint from the constraint layer. In the vibrations, the viscous shear effect of the damping layer dissipates vibration energy and converts part of the plate vibration energy into thermal energy.
Damping treatment approaches.

level3.p: In the structure with the free damping layer, the free damping layer is usually treated by hot adhesion or pasting a layer of asphalt-type damping materials on the plate. In the constraint damping layer structure, aluminum foil is one type of structure used as a constraint layer. Another type uses two thin plates to switch a viscous damping layer with thickness about 0.025 mm, and the total thickness of the structure is close to that of typical vehicle steel sheet (0.8 mm). In real applications, the total thickness of the switched structure is thicker than that of standard vehicle steel sheet, allowing it to retain a similar stiffness [36]. This kind of structure has been widely used in oil pans. It is also used in the dash, floor, and body walls. The material damping and structure damping are characterized by the following approaches. Assume that the material damping is quantified by using Young’s modulus and shear modulus. The complex Young’s modulus is E = E′+jE″ = E′(1+j E″/E′).

There are many test methods suitable to characterize damping of varied structures and material specimens. Typically, a small specimen is a beam-like structure, a middle-level specimen could be a plate-type structure, and a larger specimen or sample includes a body wall or even the entire body and vehicle structures. Beam-type samples are used most widely, the damping of beams is usually tested in terms of specification SAE J1637. SAE J1637 applies a standard beam sample, measures the first-order and several low-order mode damping under different temperatures, then uses interpolation to obtain the damping value at 200 Hz as a final result.
shows the schematic of the test system. Another test standard, ASTM E756, is not used as often as SAE J1637 [37].

Schematic of the test system for SAE J1637: 1. beam specimen of steel; 2. damping materials to be measured; 3. fixture; 4. exciter; 5. accelerometer; 6. thermal couple; 7. single amplifier; 8. spectrum analyzer; 9. signal generator; 10. thermal chamber.
There is no standard test method to quantify plate damping. A widely used method is to fix the plate sample on a frame fixture whose framework is excited by an exciter, as shown in

. Actually, the sample undergoes displacement excitation of the fixture, which is close to the excitation manner of a plate on a vehicle. The plate vibrations are measured using an accelerometer. The measurement system may include a small anechoic chamber to measure the sound pressure radiated by the plate. The damping effects of different plates can be evaluated by comparing the measured accelerations and sound pressure levels [38].
Schematic of a damping measurement system: 1. exciter; 2. test plate; 3. accelerometer; 4. microphone; 5. shield chamber (with acoustic absorption material inside).

level3.p: In product development, a damping test is conducted for a real body panel or even the entire body. The beam and plate test is not sufficient to quantify the real damping of vehicle structural parts. Solder and rivet could cause extra damping; carpet and other acoustic treatment could add extra damping to the system. In fact, even before adding extra damping layer treatment, the plate on the body has higher damping than that of the unassembled plate by one order of magnitude. The measurement of the damping of the real body panel and body are usually conducted using a commercial testing system for experimental mode analysis. The testing method includes an experimental mode analysis and free response decay approach [39].

p.span: For the vibration problem with a wideband frequency, the average of damping within a certain frequency octave is needed. The entire body can be installed on an exciter. The damping of the panel can be measured by hanging it on a fixture and conducting modal testing. The sound transmission loss testing of the panel can be conducted by mounting it on the measurement window of an anechoic chamber, by which the structure damping, vibrations, sound radiation coefficient, and sound transmission characteristics can be quantified. The frequently used index for quantifying vibrations and noise attributes of body structures is vibrations and acoustic sensitivity. The acoustic sensitivity of a vehicle body is referred to as the noise sound pressure level measured at the location of the driver’s ear

when a unit excitation force is applied at the support point of the body; it is represented by P/F with units in decibels with respect to 20 µPa/N. According to experience, the acoustic sensitivity of the vehicle body usually should be smaller than 55 dB. For the body with acoustic sensitivity of 55 dB, if excitation force is 10 N, the measured noise at the driver’s ear is 75 dB. Conceptually, the acoustic sensitivity of the vehicle body, P/F, can be separated into two parts, V/F and P/V. V/F represents the vibration transfer function of the body, whereas P/V represents the quantity of the sound pressure created by vibrations: P/F = P/V * V/F.

The partition of P/F into P/V and V/F helps to clarify the contributions of three factors: mass, stiffness, and damping. When the vibration frequency is lower than a specific mode frequency of the body, the increase in stiffness helps to reduce V/F. When the vibration frequency is higher than a certain mode frequency of the body, the increase in mass helps to reduce V/F. The optimal locations for adding extra stiffness or mass for frequency tuning depend on the mode shapes. When vibration frequency is close to a specific mode frequency of the body, the increase in damping is helpful for the reduction of V/F. If mode frequency has a high density in certain of the frequency band, the damping’s effect is stronger than that of stiffness and mass. Stiffness has a direct effect on P/V, whereas damping’s effect on P/V is negligible, which can be seen from the formula of sound radiation efficiency of the

plane plate. The mass’s effect on P/V is mainly on the separation of mode frequency, otherwise it has a negligible effect. The damping effect here is only referred to as damping characteristic. This is different from the previously mentioned damping treatment. In the damping treatment, not only damping is added, but also mass and stiffness are changed, accordingly. In fact, in the application of damping structures, for the constraint damping structure, the objective of treatment usually includes increasing both stiffness and damping; whereas for the free damping structure, the objective of treatment usually includes increasing both mass area density of plate and damping.

level3.p: Another evaluation index concerning body structure design and acoustic sensitivity is the sound quality of the door closing. It is a transient vibro-sound event. One of the design options is to add damping treatment to the door, case box exterior plate and cover, trunk panel, and roof panel to make use of damping to attenuate transient vibrations and sound radiation. For this situation, the damping treatment is purely focused on damping enhancement. Interior noise of the vehicle is the product of the body acoustic sensitivity and excitation. To reduce interior noise, the vehicle design requires not only reducing body acoustic sensitivity, but also reducing excitations and the transmissions. For body design, each supporting point of the body needs proper dynamic stiffness [40–49].

level3.p: These are discussed in following sections [6]:

list.li: Intake noise: This is related to engine speed. The air cleaning box also radiates noise.

Exhaust noise: it consists of tailpipe noise, exhaust pipe, and component radiated noise. The tailpipe noise depends on the engine speed. At higher speed, the friction noise is dominant, and is dependent on speed.
Engine radiated noise: low frequency noise is radiated from body, cylinder block, sump, and covers and depends on speed.
Tire-road noise: the contribution of tire-road noise becomes dominates at higher speeds
Wind noise: when vehicle speed is lower than 60 km/h, this noise can be ignored

level3.p: Some of the conditions that give rise to noise and vibrations in engines includes [8]:

list.li: Idling: these conditions persist when a vehicle is jammed in traffic or waiting for a service. During these conditions idle conditions vibration arise due to engine unbalanced forces in cranktrain, valve train and engine combustion torque.
Throttle condition - the vehicle may be accelerated with wide or partially opened throttle. During wide open throttle condition, combustion based noise is maximum levels.

Cruising – here the vehicle is driven at certain constant acceleration or deceleration. As an engine starts, its speed could due to low temperatures [9]. The idling speed is usually set at about 600–700 RPM. Noise under wide throttling condition could be one of the most effective [10]. The in wide open condition is higher than that of partial throttle conditions under all testing speeds [11].

level2.p: Various methods to evaluate NVH performance of engines have been discussed in this part of the work. Time-frequency analysis can help to detect individual events occurring during an engine cycle if applied to acoustic signals. Various acoustic parameters, e.g., sharpness, roughness and loudness can be evaluated to compare performance of various engines. Further, a jury of experts may scale various engines on a suitable 10-point scale.
Some of these include methods to evaluate NVH performance includes:

list.li: Quantification of various noise emissions-Various subjects may be asked to rank sound emissions from engine according to annoyance in a scale of 1 to10. However, number of samples must be kept low to avoid complexity [18].
Objective approach-Various psychoacoustic indices that can be used for evaluation includes – Loudness, Sharpness, Roughness an impulsiveness [19, 20].
